issues.description: Task 01 in the problem statement asks for data from the table `Badeanstalten` (problem_statement.md lines 106-109), but both the template (template_repository/aufgabe01.sql) and the solution (solution_repository/aufgabe01.sql) use the table `Schwimmbad`. This mismatch of the referenced table name will confuse students (they may look for `Badeanstalten` in the schema or try to run queries against a non-existent table) and can block them from implementing or testing the intended query.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the table name consistent across artifacts. Either change the problem statement to refer to the `Schwimmbad` table (e.g. "...aus der Tabelle `Schwimmbad`") or rename/update the template and solution to use `Badeanstalten` so all three artifacts reference the same table. Ensure any example columns mentioned (id, name, art, url) match the chosen table's actual column names.

issues.description: The problem statement asks for data from the table `Badeanstalten` (task text: "... aus der Tabelle `Badeanstalten` ausgibt."), but both the template and the reference solution use the table name `Schwimmbad`. This inconsistent naming for the same conceptual entity (the table containing bathing facilities) can confuse students: they may look for a `Badeanstalten` table in the starter code or solution and fail to map the task requirement to the provided SQL template/solution.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the table name consistent across artifacts. Either change the problem statement to refer to the `Schwimmbad` table (preferred, since template and solution use it) or rename the table in the template and solution to `Badeanstalten`. Update the task text to match the chosen table name so students can unambiguously map the requirement to the starter code.
